MemberSignature.Value: public System.Collections.Concurrent.ConcurrentDictionary<Type,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IFileStagingArtifact> AddTask (string jobId, Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask taskToAdd, System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior> additionalBehaviors = null);

.method public hidebysig instance class System.Collections.Concurrent.ConcurrentDictionary`2<class System.Type, class Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IFileStagingArtifact> AddTask(string jobId, class Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask taskToAdd, class System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1<class Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior> additionalBehaviors) cil managed

Docs.param: The id of the job to which to add the task.
The to add.
A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
Docs.summary: Adds a single task to a job. To add multiple tasks, use JobOperations.AddTaskAsync.
Docs.returns: A collection of information about the file staging process (see ). For more information see .

remarks.para: Each call to this method incurs a request to the Batch service. Therefore, using this method to add multiple tasks is less efficient than using a bulk add method, and can incur HTTP connection restrictions. If you are performing many of these operations in parallel and are seeing client side timeouts, please see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.servicepointmanager.defaultconnectionlimit%28v=vs.110%29.aspx or use the multiple-task overload of AddTask.
This is a blocking operation. For a non-blocking equivalent, see .

MemberSignature.Value: public void AddTask (string jobId, System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask> tasksToAdd, Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientParallelOptions parallelOptions = null, System.Collections.Concurrent.ConcurrentBag<System.Collections.Concurrent.ConcurrentDictionary<Type,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IFileStagingArtifact>> fileStagingArtifacts = null, Nullable<TimeSpan> timeout = null, System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior> additionalBehaviors = null);

.method public hidebysig instance void AddTask(string jobId, class System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1<class Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask> tasksToAdd, class Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientParallelOptions parallelOptions, class System.Collections.Concurrent.ConcurrentBag`1<class System.Collections.Concurrent.ConcurrentDictionary`2<class System.Type, class Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IFileStagingArtifact>> fileStagingArtifacts, valuetype System.Nullable`1<valuetype System.TimeSpan> timeout, class System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1<class Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior> additionalBehaviors) cil managed

Docs.param: The id of the job to which to add the tasks.
The s to add.

Controls the number of simultaneous parallel AddTaskCollection requests issued to the Batch service. Each AddTaskCollection request contains at most tasks in it. Also controls the cancellation token for the operation. If omitted, the default is used (see .)

An optional collection to receive information about the file staging process (see ). An entry is added to the for each set of tasks grouped for submission to the Batch service. Unlike single-task adds, you cannot use this parameter to customize the file staging process. For more information about the format of each entry, see .
The amount of time after which the operation times out.
A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
Docs.summary: Adds tasks to a job.

remarks.para: This is a blocking operation; for a non-blocking equivalent, see .

This method is not atomic; that is, it is possible for the method to start adding tasks and then fail. The collection of tasks to add is broken down into chunks of size at most , and an AddTaskCollection request is issued for each chunk. Requests may be issued in parallel according to the .

Issuing a large number of simultaneous requests to the Batch service can incur HTTP connection restrictions. If you are performing many of these operations in parallel (or have specified a large MaxDegreeOfParallelism in the parallelOptions) and are seeing client side timeouts, please see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.servicepointmanager.defaultconnectionlimit%28v=vs.110%29.aspx .

The progress of the operation in the face of errors is determined by behavior. You do not normally need to specify this behavior, as the Batch client uses a default which works in normal circumstances. If you do want to customize this behavior, specify an AddTaskCollectionResultHandler in the or collections.

Docs.exception: Thrown if one or more requests to the Batch service fail.

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Threading.Tasks.Task AddTaskAsync (string jobId, Microsoft.Azure.Batch.CloudTask taskToAdd, System.Collections.Concurrent.ConcurrentDictionary<Type,Microsoft.Azure.Batch.IFileStagingArtifact> allFileStagingArtifacts = null, System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior> additionalBehaviors = null, System.Threading.CancellationToken cancellationToken = null);

The to add.

A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
A for controlling the lifetime of the asynchronous operation.
Docs.summary: Adds a single task to a job. To add multiple tasks, use JobOperations.AddTaskAsync.
Docs.returns: A object that represents the asynchronous operation.

remarks.para: Each call to this method incurs a request to the Batch service. Therefore, using this method to add multiple tasks is less efficient than using a bulk add method, and can incur HTTP connection restrictions. If you are performing many of these operations in parallel and are seeing client side timeouts, please see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.servicepointmanager.defaultconnectionlimit%28v=vs.110%29.aspx or use the multiple-task overload of AddTaskAsync.
The add task operation runs asynchronously.

Docs.summary: Adds tasks to a job.
Docs.returns: A object that represents the asynchronous operation.

remarks.para: The add task operation runs asynchronously.

This method is not atomic; that is, it is possible for the method to start adding tasks and then fail. The collection of tasks to add is broken down into chunks of size at most , and an AddTaskCollection request is issued for each chunk. Requests may be issued in parallel according to the .

Issuing a large number of simultaneous requests to the Batch service can incur HTTP connection restrictions. If you are performing many of these operations in parallel (or have specified a large MaxDegreeOfParallelism in the parallelOptions) and are seeing client side timeouts, please see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.net.servicepointmanager.defaultconnectionlimit%28v=vs.110%29.aspx .

The progress of the operation in the face of errors is determined by behavior. You do not normally need to specify this behavior, as the Batch client uses a default which works in normal circumstances. Docs.summary: Creates an instance of CloudJob that is unbound and does not have a consistency relationship to any job in the Batch Service.

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Collections.Generic.IList<Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior> CustomBehaviors { get; set; }
.property instance class System.Collections.Generic.IList`1<class Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior> CustomBehaviors

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a list of behaviors that modify or customize requests to the Batch service made via this .

remarks.para: These behaviors are inherited by child objects.
Modifications are applied in the order of the collection. The last write wins.

MemberSignature.Value: public void DeleteJob (string jobId, System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior> additionalBehaviors = null);
.method public hidebysig instance void DeleteJob(string jobId, class System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1<class Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior> additionalBehaviors) cil managed

Docs.param: The id of the job.
A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
Docs.summary: Deletes the specified job.

remarks.para: The delete operation requests that the job be deleted. The request puts the job in the state. The Batch service will stop any running tasks and perform the actual job deletion without any further client action.
This is a blocking operation. For a non-blocking equivalent, see .

MemberSignature.Value: public void DeleteNodeFile (string jobId, string taskId, string filePath, Nullable<bool> recursive = null, System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior> additionalBehaviors = null);

.method public hidebysig instance void DeleteNodeFile(string jobId, string taskId, string filePath, valuetype System.Nullable`1<bool> recursive, class System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1<class Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior> additionalBehaviors) cil managed

Docs.param: The id of the job containing the task.
The id of the task.
The path of the file to delete.

If the file-path parameter represents a directory instead of a file, you can set the optional recursive parameter to true to delete the directory and all of the files and subdirectories in it. If recursive is false then the directory must be empty or deletion will fail.
A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
Docs.summary: Deletes the specified file from the task's directory on its compute node.
Docs.returns: A that represents the asynchronous operation.
Docs.remarks: This is a blocking operation. For a non-blocking equivalent, see .

MemberSignature.Value: public void ReactivateTask (string jobId, string taskId, System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior> additionalBehaviors = null);

.method public hidebysig instance void ReactivateTask(string jobId, string taskId, class System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1<class Microsoft.Azure.Batch.BatchClientBehavior> additionalBehaviors) cil managed

Docs.param: The id of the job containing the task.
The id of the task.
A collection of instances that are applied to the Batch service request after the .
Docs.summary: Reactivates a task, allowing it to run again even if its retry count has been exhausted.

remarks.para: Reactivation makes a task eligible to be retried again up to its maximum retry count.
This operation will fail for tasks that are not completed or that previously completed successfully (with an exit code of 0).
Additionally, this will fail if the job is in the or or state. This is a blocking operation. For a non-blocking equivalent, see .
